Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: A Remarkable New Fossil Assemblage from the Burgess Shale at Marble Canyon, Kootenay National Park
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Cambrian ?explosion? was a singular event in the history of life on Earth. This episode, which saw the origin and rapid diversification of almost all major groups of animals (phyla), serves to divide the entire geologic record into two parts, the Precambrian and Phanerozoic Eons. By far, the best records of this event come from a handful of exceptional fossil deposits that preserve the ?soft?, non-biomineralized tissues of organisms that normally leave no trace in the fossil record. Such deposits offer not only a remarkable view of the early patterns of evolution, but have helped to reveal the basic structure of the animal family tree. Recently, the most important Cambrian fossil assemblage discovered in decades was reported from the Burgess Shale near Marble Canyon.
This project seeks to provide baseline characterization of the new fossil assemblage and its geological and geochemical context though a multi-disciplinary approach, which will provide hands on training for undergraduates and a postdoctoral scholar. The goals of the project are: 1. to document the geographic extent and composition of the new fossil fauna by exploration and quarrying; 2. to use geochemical and sedimentologic methods to reconstruct the nature of ancient environments in which these fossil assemblages thrived; 3. to develop a strontium isotope chronology linking all Burgess Shale localities in relative time, and; 4. to determine the origin of the Cathedral Escarpment, an enigmatic topographic feature that is central to the Geologic history of the Burgess Shale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Collaborative Research — A Remarkable New Fossil Assemblage from the Burgess Shale at Marble Canyon, Kootenay National Park 

 

This project, in collaboration with Robert Gaines, Pomona College, focused on a remarkable new soft-bodied assemblage from the Burgess Shale was discovered near Marble Canyon, British Columbia and the potential to use strontium (Sr) isotopic compositions of the marine carbonates in which the fossils are hosted for improved time control and correlation between outcrops and fossil horizons. The new assemblage is distinct and is characterized by an unexpectedly large proportion of new taxa (>25%) and an unusually high fidelity of soft-bodied preservation, which provides new anatomical information from many previously known forms. The relatively broad distribution of the assemblage offered unique opportunities for study of ecological and environmental dynamics in large geographic region. Our primary goal was to comprehensively document the diversity and paleoenvironmental context of the Marble Canyon assemblage through a field campaign and intensive lab work integrating taxonomic, paleoecologic, sedimentologic and geochemical methods.  The research was guided by three major goals. First, to develop a detailed understanding of the environmental setting in which the soft bodied organisms were preserved. Insight into the paleo-oceanographic environment is critical to understanding what processes permitted preservation of the fauna. Second, to carry out a thorough study of post-depositional alteration history of the carbonates in the Cambrian successions that host the fossil assemblages. And third, to develop a Sr isotope framework that can be used to constraint the age of the deposits and to correlate all Burgess Shale fossil localities found regionally in relative time. 

Intellectual Merit: There outcomes and findings of the award will impact other studies of the evolution of early life and the associated Cambrian environments. First, through a detailed petrographic and geochemical analysis of marine carbonates from Middle to early Late Cambrian successions in the U.S. Great Basin and Canadian Rockies, we have documented compositional heterogeneity on a sub-100 µm scale that is unresolvable by physical sampling methods for the more widely used solution Sr isotope analysis.  These Cambrian carbonates are comparable to many other marine carbonates in the geologic archive and thus our results can be applied to other studies.  Specifically, this study highlights that physical sampling of ancient marine carbonates can potentially artificially homogenize material, which is chemically and isotopically heterogeneous leading to erroneous Sr isotope results. Second, we document the high potential of in situ analysis of Sr isotope values in ancient marine carbonates by laser ablation multi-collector inductively coupled argon plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICP-MS) to analyze discrete generations and/or best-preserved areas of marine cements. This approach may provide the highest potential for resolving primary marine Sr isotope signatures in other ancient carbonate successions. Third, we present a robust seawater Sr isotope curve for the Middle to early Late Cambrian time period that fully revises the previously published record of Montañez et al. (1996; 2000).  The new Sr isotope curve is characterized by sseveral shorter-term rises and falls that offer improved time control (i.e. chronostratigraphy) for the Cambrian sedimentary geology and paleobiology community. 

Broader Impacts:  This award supported the education and mentoring of a M.S. student and post-doctoral scholar at UC Davis, an institution that strives to provide transformative research experiences for under-represented students and early career professionals. This included extensive exposure to the graduate student to challenging field work as well as training in multiple novel geochemical skills. The research supported by this award promoted the sharing of the findings with peers and students at a national conference and a student-led publication. In order to assure that the data and findings of this research are available to those who are interested, all of the data from this research have been deposited in Dryad, a FAIR-aligned repository for scientific data and the details of the methodology, samples, tables of all measurements and calculated values, and all statistical evaluations of the data are made available in Supplementary Online Materials associated with the manuscripts we publish.
